article: Why Is Your First Alert Smoke Alarm Beeping/Chirping?
intro: Do you know the variations of beeps of a First Alert smoke alarm? Beeps sound different depending on the situation, and this wikiHow guide goes over that difference as well as lists some troubleshooting steps you can take to stop the alarm from beeping.

steps.title: Loud beeping is an emergency, but the unit chirps to indicate issues.
steps.subtitle: It's a good idea to learn the difference between the two sounds:
sub-points: 3 beeps with a pause is an emergency sound; your unit has detected smoke and/or CO. You need to evacuate your house and call .
Softer, shorter beeps indicate low battery or some other issue. The next section lists fixes for issues that could make your First Alert Smoke Alarm chirp.

steps.title: Loud beeping is an emergency, but the unit chirps to indicate issues.
steps.subtitle: It's a good idea to learn the difference between the two sounds:
sub-points: 3 beeps with a pause is an emergency sound; your unit has detected smoke and/or CO. You need to evacuate your house and call .
Softer, shorter beeps indicate low battery or some other issue. The next section lists fixes for issues that could make your First Alert Smoke Alarm chirp.

steps.title: Move the detector somewhere else.
steps.subtitle: Some locations are bad for alarms and smoke detectors, so any in these places can have nuisance alarms (alarms triggered by environmental factors, not CO or smoke).
sub-points: Bad locations include dusty, dirty, greasy areas like garages, but also areas with combustion particles, like kitchens. You also want to avoid putting your CO alarm or smoke detector in high-humidity areas like your bathroom.
Install the unit at least 5 feet away from any cooking appliance and 10 feet away from anything that creates humidity.
Refer to  for more dos and don'ts.

steps.title: Silence nuisance alarms and low battery chirps.
steps.subtitle: You can stop nuisance alarms (like those triggered by dust) for several minutes or stop the battery chirp for up to 8 hours. If you silence a smoke detector, the alarm will stay off for 15 minutes, but will sound again if the smoke has not dissipated or has increased. If you silence a CO detector, it will stay off for 4 minutes, but if the CO levels are still high, the alarm will beep again. There are two ways that you can silence your alarms:
sub-points: Open the Onelink Home app and tap .
Press the Test/Silence button on your unit.
